title: Wnt, Ptk7, and FGFRL expression gradients control trunk positional identity in planarian regeneration
abstract: Mechanisms enabling positional identity re-establishment are likely critical for tissue regeneration. Planarians use Wnt/beta-catenin signaling to polarize the termini of their anteroposterior axis, but little is known about how regeneration signaling restores regionalization along body or organ axes. We identify three genes expressed constitutively in overlapping body-wide transcriptional gradients that control trunk-tail positional identity in regeneration. <italic>ptk7</italic> encodes a trunk-expressed kinase-dead Wnt co-receptor, <italic>wntP-2</italic> encodes a posterior-expressed Wnt ligand, and <italic>ndl-3</italic> encodes an anterior-expressed homolog of conserved FGFRL/<italic>nou-darake</italic> decoy receptors. <italic>ptk7</italic> and <italic>wntP-2</italic> maintain and allow appropriate regeneration of trunk tissue position independently of canonical Wnt signaling and with suppression of <italic>ndl-3</italic> expression in the posterior. These results suggest that restoration of regional identity in regeneration involves the interpretation and re-establishment of axis-wide transcriptional gradients of signaling molecules.
